We investigated the use of a silver standard corpus ( SSC ) that is automatically generated by combining the outputs of multiple chunking systems .We explored two use scenarios : one in which chunkers are trained on an SSC in a new domain for which a GSC is not available , and one in which chunkers are trained on an available , although small GSC but supplemented with an SSC .

We have tested the two scenarios using three chunkers , Lingpipe , OpenNLP , and Yamcha , and two different corpora , GENIA and PennBioIE .When the outputs of the chunkers were combined , the combined system showed little improvement when using the SSC .

In this study we investigate an alternative , automatic approach to create an annotated corpus .We have shown before that a system combining the outputs of various chunkers performs better than each of the individual chunkers .Here we postulate that the annotations of such a combined system on a given corpus can be taken as a reference standard , establishing a " silver standard corpus " ( SSC ) .
